title: Will an early election or a recall referendum take place in Venezuela before 1 July 2017?
preds:
Helicopter attacks Venezuela court, Maduro denounces coup bid Ramírez and Chinea (2017) Tue Jun 27, states that: A Venezuelan police helicopter strafed the Supreme Court and a government ministry on Tuesday, escalating the OPEC nation's political crisis in what President Nicolas Maduro called an attack by "terrorists" seeking a coup. The aircraft fired 15 shots at the Interior Ministry, where scores of people were at a social event, and dropped four grenades on the court, where judges were meeting, officials said. However, there were no reports of injuries. "Sooner rather than later, we are going to capture the helicopter and those behind this armed terrorist attack against the institutions of the country," Maduro said. "They could have caused dozens of deaths," he said. The 54-year-old socialist leader has faced three months of protests from opposition leaders who decry him as a dictator who has wrecked a once-prosperous economy. There has been growing dissent too from within government and the security forces. At least 75 people have died, and hundreds more been injured and arrested, in the anti-government unrest since April. Demonstrators are demanding general elections, measures to alleviate a brutal economic crisis, freedom for hundreds of jailed opposition activists, and independence for the opposition-controlled National Assembly legislature. Maduro says they are seeking a coup against him with the encouragement of a U.S. government eager to gain control of Venezuela's oil reserves, the largest in the world. Venezuela's government said in a communique the helicopter was stolen by an investigative police pilot called Oscar Perez, who declared himself in rebellion against Maduro (para 1-8). Ramírez, S. & Chinea, E. (2017). Helicopter attacks Venezuela court, Maduro denounces coup bid. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKBN19I2RV

that's only 15 days from now, I think the dictatorship will fall but it will take another month or two, then they need to get ready for a constitutional real election, in order for that to happen the assembly has to purge the electoral system which is run by corrupt people right now.

There is no way the current Maduro administration will risk further dissent and continued destabilization of the economy by hosting a referendum until the last possible moment. He has nothing to gain by holding the referendum by July 1 because there is no penalty to do so.
The Government of Venezuela has no reason to hold a referendum before July 1. They have every incentive to promise a referendum for later in the year.

Violence engulfs Venezuelan capital, teenage protester dies Cawthorne (2017) Wed Jun 7, states that: A 17-year-old Venezuelan protester died in ferocious clashes between security forces and protesters in Caracas on Wednesday, taking the death toll from unrest since April to at least 66. The government said Neomar Lander died when a homemade mortar exploded in his hands while hundreds of youths faced off with National Guard troops in the Venezuelan capital. Opposition lawmakers, however, said he was killed by a tear gas canister fired straight at him. The state prosecutor's office announced a probe, without giving details (para. 1-3). Critics denounce Maduro as a repressive dictator, and are demanding general elections, foreign humanitarian aid, freedom for hundreds of jailed activists, and autonomy for the opposition-controlled National Assembly (para. 7). "We mustn't let fear intimidate us, let's stay in the streets to fight for all Venezuelans' future," said opposition lawmaker Miguel Pizarro, weeping at a news conference as he described seeing Lander's death. "Soon we will able to say these were the last, dark days of the dictatorship." Maduro, 54, calls his foes violent right-wing "fascist" conspirators seeking a coup similar to the short-lived 2002 toppling of his predecessor Hugo Chavez. "This is criminal terrorism, and we must reject it," Maduro told supporters in a speech carried on state TV, comparing his foes to Adolf Hitler, Benito Mussolini and Augusto Pinochet. ECONOMIC CRISIS In the worst turmoil of Maduro's turbulent four-year rule, thousands of people have been injured and arrested in recent weeks. Protesters are also complaining about hunger and shortages during a brutal economic crisis in the OPEC nation. In Caracas on Wednesday, security forces using armored vehicles, water cannons and tear gas blocked opposition supporters from marching to the national election board's headquarters, sparking clashes around the city (para. 7-13). Cawthorne, A. (2017). Violence engulfs Venezuelan capital, teenage protester dies. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKBN18Y3B3

Venezuela's Maduro vows referendum, death toll from unrest hits 62 Oré and Cawthorne (2017) Thu Jun 1, states that: Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro pledged on Thursday to hold a referendum on a new constitution he has proposed to try and quell two months of anti-government unrest that has killed at least 62 people. His comments came after criticism from opponents and some within his own government that his plan to create a new super-body, known as a constituent assembly, to rewrite the national charter was anti-democratic. Chief state prosecutor Luisa Ortega had said creating the assembly without a plebiscite, as happened in 1999 when Maduro's predecessor Hugo Chavez rewrote the constitution, threatened to "eliminate" democracy in Venezuela. Maduro said on state television: "I shall propose it explicitly: the new constitution will go to a consultative referendum so it is the people who say whether they are in agreement or not with the new, strengthened constitution." There was no immediate reaction from Venezuela's opposition, which now has majority support after years in the shadow of the ruling Socialist Party whose popularity has plunged during the OPEC nation's brutal economic crisis. Foes are likely to try and turn any referendum into a vote on Maduro himself. They have been calling for the next presidential election, slated for late 2018, to be brought forward. **The government has said elections for the new constituent assembly will be held in late July**, although opposition leaders say the process is skewed to ensure a pro-Maduro majority (para 1-7). Oré, D. & Cawthorne, A. (2017). Venezuela's Maduro vows referendum, death toll from unrest hits 62. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKBN18S5O4

https://www.dailysabah.com/americas/2017/05/26/barricades-protests-spread-after-venezuela-election-dates-set After nearly two months of protests demanding an early presidential vote, the pro-government electoral council on Tuesday said voting for a controversial "constituent assembly" would be held in July and delayed state elections in December.
Too soon. An election may be allowed, but not that quickly.
The quickest election will held at the end of Q4 2017, or highly possible at Q1 2018

Venezuela is in the grip of a major crisis. For the last month, hundreds of thousands of protesters demonstrating against the government of President Nicolas Maduro have been met by riot police almost daily.
What happens now will depend on the people on the streets, "but also on the military," McCoy said.
She added that Maduro's call for a constitutional rewrite "looks like a gambit by the president to calm the current unrest in the streets and postpone elections that he fears he will lose."
"The next step will depend on how big of an outcry there is in Venezuela and if the military continues to support the president or if there is international outcry."
http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/venezuela-crisis/venezuela-protests-economic-crisis-what-going-n755306

COMMENT:  Maduro will not allow elections; he will certainly loose them. I'm afraid that Maduro will leave the Presidential Palace only "feet first"
One might be announced if things get too hairy for Maduro, but less likely to happen so quickly.
Probably be a while before anybody in Venezuela gets to vote on anything important in any election that is remotely honest.  To borrow an expression from the US president, "Sad!"

Venezuela death toll rises as unrest enters fourth week Oré and Ellsworth (2017) Mon Apr 24, states that: Gunmen killed two more people during political unrest in Venezuela on Monday, bringing the total number of deaths to 12 this month, as anti-government protests entered a fourth week with mass "sit-ins" to press for early elections (para. 1). The ruling Socialist Party accuses foes of seeking a violent coup with U.S. connivance, while the opposition says he is a dictator repressing peaceful protest (para. 7). The opposition's main demands are for elections, the release of jailed activists and autonomy for the opposition-led congress. But protests are also fueled by the crippling economic crisis in the oil-rich nation of 30 million people. "I have an empty stomach because I can't find food," said Jeannette Canozo, a 66-year-old homemaker, who said police used rubber bullets against protesters blocking a Caracas avenue with trash and bathtubs in the early morning. Demonstrators wore the yellow, blue and red colors of Venezuela's flag and held signs denouncing shortages, inflation and violent crime as they chanted: "This government has fallen!" In the capital, they streamed from several points onto a major highway, where hundreds of people sat, carrying bags of supplies, playing card games, and shielding themselves from the sun with hats and umbrellas (para. 7-12). Oré, D. & Ellsworth, B. (2017). Venezuela death toll rises as unrest enters fourth week. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-idUSKBN17Q1KO

Faced with massive protests, Maduro has called for local elections of governors and mayors.  The presidential election is still slated for 2018.

Venezuela seized GM's car plant today.
Violent protests continue, some people have reportedly died in confrontation with government forces or Maduros' loyalists. 
Economic crisis continues to worsen.  At the end of March, the country only had $10.5 billion in foreign reserves left and owed some $7.2 billion in outstanding debt payments.  In 2011, the country had $30 billion in reserves, and $20 billion in 2015. Imports are down 50% from a year ago. Maduro is continued to be defiant, showing no signs of wanting to reach a resolution in this latest crisis.    Source: http://money.cnn.com/2017/03/01/news/economy/venezuela-cash/index.html?iid=EL
dropping from one to zero because I've now lost hope for a decent resolution to the crisis in Venezuela.

http://country.eiu.com/venezuela
"In brief - Notwithstanding his low popularity amid economic crisis, supply shortages and high inflation, we expect the president, Nicolás Maduro, to retain power with the support of the military until the December 2018 election, which we expect the opposition MUD to win." I've been at 1% since December 2016. Maduro has shut down all legal ways that could remove him, leaving a military coup as the only option. However, even if he suddenly loses its support, and the military decides to hold an election rather than take power itself, this question closes in 85 days, which doesn't leave sufficient time for a credible election to be organized.

Venezuela’s Government Scraps Ruling to Dissolve Congress Kurmanaev and Vyas (2017) April 1, states that: CARACAS, Venezuela—Venezuela’s Supreme Court on Saturday scrapped parts of a ruling that had dissolved the National Assembly, but the move was unlikely to quell concerns over President Nicolás Maduro’s slide toward authoritarian rule. Court magistrates, who are close allies of Mr. Maduro, said they reinstated powers that they had taken from the opposition-controlled assembly and returned the immunity from investigation granted to lawmakers. “Rest assured that we will never do anything that threatens the stability of the country,” Chief Justice Maikel Moreno, flanked by Vice President Tareck El Aissami, said in an address to more than 70 foreign diplomats. The court order had drawn international outrage and condemnation from rights groups as well as the nation’s attorney general, a rare voice of dissent from within the ruling Socialist Party’s ranks. Earlier in the day, Mr. Maduro said in a televised speech that the dispute had been resolved after a four-hour meeting with top officials. The president last night urged the court to revise its decision to strip the unicameral assembly of its powers, an act he said demonstrated Venezuela’s vibrant democracy and the separation of powers. Constitutional experts, however, said it did exactly the opposite. “There is no way to revise a Supreme Court sentence by order of the president,” said Antonio Canova, a constitutional law professor at Andres Bello Catholic University in Caracas. “Once they’re published they can’t be modified. It’s now clearer than ever that the court works unconditionally for Maduro. It is evident that we are facing a dictatorship.” Opposition leaders said the government’s olive branch does nothing to assuage Mr. Maduro’s power grab. “Nothing changed last night. There’s a coup going on,” National Assembly leader Julio Borges said at a rally Saturday in an eastern Caracas plaza where the opposition majority convened an open-air legislative session (para. 1-7). Kurmanaev, A. & Vyas, K. (2017). Venezuela’s Government Scraps Ruling to Dissolve Congress. The Wall Street Journal. World. Latin America. Retrieved from 
https://www.wsj.com/articles/maduro-seeks-to-diffuse-tensions-in-venezuela-1491050119

Venezuela Lurches Toward Dictatorship as Top Court Seizes Power Rosati (2017) March 30, states that: Venezuela slid closer toward dictatorship after the country’s Supreme Court gutted the only opposition-run institution -- the Congress -- seizing its powers and declaring the elected body invalid.
The court’s ruling late on Wednesday night was, in the words of lawmakers, nothing short of a coup. Several opposition leaders called for street demonstrations and other forms of “democratic resistance.”
As the once-wealthy oil power descends into a chaos of hunger and crime, however, it remained far from clear whether the increasingly despondent population will view the court’s move as a genuine turning point or just another step in the nation’s bottoming out toward hopelessness.
“This is not only going to cause alarm for concern within the region, but also actions, and at this point, it will be very difficult for countries to remain neutral,” said Carlos Romero, a political scientist at the Central University of Venezuela in Caracas. “The government is provoking; not only has it not made a single gesture toward dialog, it has become completely entrenched.”
Opposition deputies said they would appeal to international bodies for help. But that may yield little. Two days before the court’s ruling, the Organization of American States met to urge Venezuela to respect the congress that has now been neutered.
The U.S. State Department condemned the Supreme Court’s decision on Thursday, saying the move "greatly damages Venezuela’s democratic institutions," according to a statement. Constitutional Crisis In Wednesday’s ruling, the Supreme Court’s Constitutional Chamber declared the National Assembly was operating “outside the rule of law” after long standing claims that the legislature was in contempt of previous legal statements.
“The Constitutional Chamber shall ensure that the parliamentary powers are exercised directly by this Chamber or by the body it appoints to ensure the rule of law,” the decision said.
Venezuela’s dueling political factions have been at loggerheads since opponents of President Nicolas Maduro took control of the legislature last year. Since then, the Supreme Court, largely loyal to Maduro government, has curbed congress’s powers and overturned almost every piece of legislation passed. Until Wednesday though, it hadn’t gone as far as directly assuming congress’s functions (para. 1-9). Rosati, A. (2017). Venezuela Lurches Toward Dictatorship as Top Court Seizes Power. Bloomberg. Retrieved from
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-30/venezuela-s-supreme-court-takes-over-national-assembly-duties
Downgrading the chances after the virtual dissolution of its parliament
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
raising the probability here as of latest news on the streets there
I see this as more unlikely. There's no real movement on any of the entities which could pressure Venezuela to such a move

On one hand, Venezuela still has a high GDP, even a high GDP per capita as compared to its neighbors. The economic output is primarily controlled by the government, which means they still have plenty of capability to redistribute this economic wealth however they please to appease the people the more pressure is exerted on the streets.
On the other hand, there has been an acceleration of migration out of the country to other South American destinations, meaning people is choosing to flight rather than fight to an extent, which is a normal reaction one all hope is lost. 
Why I go for a 5% rather than a virtual 0% chance of this happening? Because if there were a blockade of Venezuela oil exports and a concerted effort by the American States to keep the people fed during such a process, in this scenario Maduro would be forced to relinquish power and call early elections but the likely-hood of something like this happening is extremely low. Maduro won't relinquish power unless forced under duress and he still controls a relatively fat wallet.

The only way I can see this happening is after some kind of overthrow of the government. I guess this will not happen unless the army decides that Maduro has to go. Even then the army might just try and get Maduro to work with parliament rather than hold an election. I note that the question concerns early elections or a recall referendum, not forced resignation or overthrow. I am not sure how an overthrow followed by an election would count(?)
Time passes and remain time will be very short for preparations

Venezuela falls behind on oil-for-loan deals with China, Russia
Parraga and Ellsworth (2017) Thu Feb 9, states that: Venezuela's state-run oil company, PDVSA, has fallen months behind on shipments of crude and fuel under oil-for-loan deals with China and Russia, according to internal company documents reviewed by Reuters.
The delayed shipments to such crucial political allies and trading partners - which together have extended Venezuela at least $55 billion (£43.9 billion) in credit - provide new insight into PDVSA's operational failures and their crippling impact on the country's unraveling socialist economy.
Because oil accounts for almost all of Venezuela's export revenue, PDVSA's crisis extends to a citizenry suffering through triple-digit inflation and food shortages reminiscent of the waning days of the Soviet Union.
The total worth of the late cargoes to state-run Chinese and Russian firms is about $750 million, according to a Reuters analysis of the PDVSA documents.
At the end of January, PDVSA was late on nearly 10 million barrels of refined products that the company owes the firms - with shipments delayed by as much as 10 months, according to the documents. It also failed to make timely deliveries of another 3.2 million barrels of crude shipments to China's state-run China National Petroleum Corporation (CNPC) (para.1-5) Parraga, M. & Ellsworth, B. (2017). Venezuela falls behind on oil-for-loan deals with China, Russia. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-oil-insight-idUSKBN15O2BC

Venezuelan supreme court says lawmakers get no power to impeach president Xinhua (2017) Jan 9, state that: CARACAS, Jan. 9 (Xinhua) -- Venezuela's Supreme Court of Justice on Monday said opposition legislators do not have the power to impeach the president, in accordance with the country's constitution.
The remarks came after the National Assembly, where the opposition holds the majority of seats, on Monday approved a resolution declaring that President Nicolas Maduro had "abandoned his post" and failed to perform the basic duties of governing the country.
In a statement, the court ordered lawmakers to "abstain from continuing impeachment proceedings against the president of the country, or any other type of measure that is beyond its constitutional powers."
The court also urged the opposition to pursue dialogue as a means of resolving differences (para. 1-4). New China Website. (2017). Venezuelan supreme court says lawmakers get no power to impeach president. Xinhua. Retrieved from
http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-01/10/c_135971142.htm

I am dropping my forecast from 12 to 4 percent because Maduro seems to be digging in and his recently appointed vice president is a hardliner more likely to appease Maduro's base than resolve the economic and political crisis in the country.

I see Maduro as the "friendly face" used to cover a military dictatorship*. In this constellation, I do not see how an election or a referendum would come to be; the military would greatly lose influence if a politician received a mandate from the people of Venezuela. The Vatican tried to broker a friendly outcome, but the initiative seems to have gone nowhere.**
Rather I believe that alternative outcomes are much more likely: the military replacing Maduro (they would have lots of excuses for that), a confrontation / revolution (desperation runs ever higher in the country) or a sovereign default (but the recent uptick of the oil price might have prevented that -- depending on the level of fraud excised by the rulers).  * See for example: http://www.thenewamerican.com/world-news/south-america/item/23625-venezuela-now-a-military-dictatorship
** See http://www.economist.com/blogs/erasmus/2016/10/venezuela-and-vatican

COMMENT:  Maduro knows well how to hold to power and bankrupt a country. Let's see if they pay the another tranche in February

The Trump Presidency will give Maduro renewed opportunities to accuse the US of hostility as the oil price increase lessens the economic crisis.

Early elections are a stretch... per their constitution, the only way to get early elections is if post is vacant [1].  Opposition is trying to make the case that Maduro is not at his post & therefore new elections are required.  Looks like their supreme court has already smacked down that approach [4] Recall referendum _could_ be feasible, however - in this case - "success" in a recall scenario would result in the VP (who is a hard liner and not aligned with opposition/socialist party) would take over vs. an election process; so benefits of a successful recall are not really there [2].  To achieve a recall, opposition has 3 stages: 
1) Collect signatures from 1% of population on a petition; 
2) once ratified, get 20% of population (via a second petition) to endorse recall w/in 3 days of ratification; 
3) perform recall and elect new president.   That all said - opposition achieved step 1 last Oct, however courts struck it down based on fraud allegations [3].  Some undertones that courts were influenced by Maduro camp to disqualify step 1 effort... in which case, future similar efforts might meet with same fate. [1] http://www.janes.com/article/66787/early-elections-in-venezuela-remain-unlikely-despite-opposition-efforts-to-force-presidential-removal-through-congress
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/time-runs-out-for-venezuela-to-elect-new-president/2017/01/09/6fdfdc28-d67e-11e6-a0e6-d502d6751bc8_story.html?utm_term=.a4d328b77dec
[3] http://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-37724322
[4] http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Venezuela-Court-Annuls-Opposition-Impeachment-of-Maduro-20170109-0023.html

It appears that Maduro with his packed Supreme Court will continue to be President until he is overthrown. The constitution is now just a fig leaf to cover the reality that Venezuela is a single party dictatorship. The options are (a) that Maduro continues as now (b) his party replaces him (c) the armed forces remove him. Obviously its difficult to forecast the likelihood of option "c", but as the chaos continues it must be getting more likely. From what I read option "b" is unlikely to happen and if it did would be unlikely to produce a change of government policies or competence. 
I had thought that once the result of a recall referendum if successful would only replace Maduro with his Vice President the party might allow it to take place in order to placate the opposition and demonstrate that the constitution was still being followed. I see no signs of this happening. 
The oil price increase since the November OPEC meeting has given Venezuela a breathing space, but it seems that production of fracked oil is rising again and the is lowering the price. This would suggest that fracking producers are now becoming the swing suppliers, replacing the Arab countries who were performing that role. If so that should dampen price changes. This is not good news for Venezuela that needs much higher oil prices to sort its economy out. 
I now think an overthrow is more likely than a recall or new election.

Extract from the Economist Intelligence Unit, dated 21 December 2016 - their baseline is for Maduro to ride out 2017 with military support (having shut down all legal ways through which he could be removed). Although there is a high risk of the latter turfing him out eventually because of hyperinflation, for the purposes of this question a coup won't count - only an early election or recall referendum, and six months may not be long enough for that to happen. "More of the same in 2017, but the risk of collapse persists - Our baseline scenario for 2017 is that Mr Maduro will remain in office, muddling through on the economic front. Given widespread public anger with the economic crisis, this will not reflect any kind of lingering backing from a loyal support base; instead, he will remain president by virtue of the erosion of basic constitutional rights and backed by the military. If Mr Maduro had abided by the constitution in 2016, the National Assembly would have been able to pass legislation and a recall referendum against the president would already have been held, which in all likelihood would have prompted a fresh presidential election (which the MUD would almost certainly have won). Mr Maduro is likely to remain president in 2017 simply because he has shut down all legal routes of removing him from office. With the military onside, it is difficult to see how a co-ordinated movement of anti-government demonstrations can force the president out. The role of the military will therefore remain crucial. We assume that the government will reward loyalty of the armed forces by granting them access to US dollars at the official-rate and a greater role in policymaking (the military is already in charge of food distribution). However, if hyperinflation were to take hold, the military may well judge that these privileges are not worth the price of continuing to prop up an administration that is doing such damage to the economy. This could well lead the military to withdraw its support for the government. Assuming that this scenario were to materialise in the event of heightened social unrest, the government would be likely to crumble. Although not our baseline forecast, we attach a very high risk to this scenario. Any successor government would need significant support from the IMF, given the depth of economic distortions. Dollarisation of the economy, or the launch of a new currency, would be highly likely."
Maduro has taken over all avenues of power preventing an early resolution to Venezuela's crisis of government

I don't see how this happens when Maduro controls the election commission, unless a coup occurs or something of that sort. When this question asks "take place" I cannot see how that happens before July 1, as even if the referendum were scheduled I think the early election itself would be obviated or perhaps civil  war or some other resolution

Current administration appears dug in, and will not allow any legal mechanism for early presidential election. Small probability of resignation if state loses grip on power, but seems unlikely on this timescale.
Government seems unlikely to be able to give this up even with a deep crisis.
Venezuela's president has support of the poor people in the country and won't be bullied to have a new election.

The currency crisis is creating significantly more instability on the ground than most commentators appreciate.  It may spill over sufficiently to cause new elections and/or a recall, a chance that seems to be rising.  There is the chance that the current regime will launch a bloody crackdown, but even they recognize it's getting voliatile.
Hungry people eventually force change or war.
Maduro would rather call in the army.

* For the Chavistas, The Bolivarian Revolution Must Carry On despite all economic, welfare and political turmoil/mayhem 
*  the PSUV / UBCh et al will do whatever it takes to hold power and press on.  In their thinking the BR is still way to young (18yrs now) and needs much more time to incubate and eventually reap their future socialist successes
* ANY THREAT to actually remove them from Power will be thwarted by sheer political and paramilitary / national military force
* there is no real opposition to transform the regime (no matter how incompetent the PSUV is)
* Venezuela's neighboring countries are in the midst of hanging on their own internal power issues and are of no leverage
* China will continue to take extreme leverage/advantage  into the Venezuela Resources
Assessment: Venezuela will be in this downward spiral for at least another 6 -11 yrs, till oil prices recover higher and food imports settle.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

These fellows are boringly predictable!
They will not go unless 'pushed'

Chaos reigns with the collapse of the economy and rule of law. The increasingly autocratic incumbent will deny the opposition any due process. Only a coup can topple this Government in these conditions.

Maduro may very likely be gone by July 2017 but it will not be from an election or recall referendum.  It will either be a peoples revolt or the military and existing power brokers deciding to throw him under the bus.  If I was him I would be loading up my overseas bank accounts right now.
Once the people of Venezuela see how much better life in Cuba is getting with the opening up of the economy and Fidelito gone, Maduro will be displace quickly.

If the government delays the recall referendum until 2017 and loses, the vote it will not make much difference because although Maduro would be recalled the vice-president would take over and Maduro could continue to run things (may be I should say would continue to screw things up) from the shadows.  Therefore the opposition would have little incentive to continue with the recall, apart from making the point that the citizens are unhappy, but on the other hand the government must know that already and losing a recall would make no practical difference except that the government could claim that it is honoring the constitution. My conclusion is that the government might prefer to let the recall take place if only to stop the international complaints about ignoring the constitution.
Maduro and his "gang" have proven to be very apt in delaying these things

Starting a little late on this one, as time has passed since the question was posed, I can see an increase in the probable outcome of this one.
The people in Venezuela are going to say enough in 2017, and it relates to the lack of access to basics items for daily living.
Venezuela is been run very poorly, I guess that is a global situation, it does seem that they cannot find capable managers at most levels to deal with the stupidity of the administration, by the actions of the Maduro administration, it seems that Venezuela is been run by high-schoolers with hourly tantrums. 
The game of geopolitics, Venezuela has become a cauldron for the top three players ( USA, China, Russia) to act one way or the other in the country to create a circle of influence. Venezuela is an oily business!  Putin seems the best placed for politics in relation to the present government, the US continues to fund the opposition to Maduro; and in the mean time, the Chinese are buying all they can including access and government contracts. So, the oily cauldron is going to get thick this upcoming year and let's hope that it is not too messy.

The current state of affairs in Venezuela should come to a head soon, it cannot keep getting worse indefinitely without a massive uprising. Maduro will try to hold power by force if he can or he may agree to a negotiated settlement is if it was the only way for him to escape alive or not in prison.
Rising oil prices will diminish unrest.  Still, never say never.

I am starting at 0% because all efforts to have early elections or a recall have been blocked and there are no signs the ruling party is preparing to dump Maduro. However, the economic crisis in the country is not going to go away because the government is literally destroying the private sector and no amount of oil money is going to change that. So, if oil prices rise (and I am doubtful that the OPEC deal will stick) and the problems in the economy continue, I see a small possibility that the ruling party may decide that they need to dump Maduro to survive. So I give 4 points each for either the supreme court, the election commission, or the military to decide to get rid of Maduro.

Oil price has increased. I expect the additional revenues to more than easily guarantee Maduro's success. Maduro has consistently resisted efforts to hold a recall referendum or early election. The opposition says he controls the courts and electoral authorities.

Oppressed humans will stomach the oppression as long as they are well fed history has shown repeatedly. Take away the food and they will riot and it hasn't come to this in Venezuela yet despite Maduro's unfathomable stupidity. 
Reading about his moronic "policies" does however indicate that this will probably happen, not sure when though as he will beg for money from the naive west.

He is about as far from reality as any president anywhere in the world who is already in office--tied with Mugabe at least.  However, he mostly owns the courts and the election authorities; this should prove helpful to him, if not to Venezuela.   On the other hand, people are deeply and sincerely fed up, and the courts might go rogue on him.  He will still win any election that happens along, although no one will actually vote for him.  Pretty soon after that the army will get a divorce rather than shoot up demonstrators, and his head will be tastefully displayed on a stake outside Miraflores.  Perhaps only figuratively.
Maduro should read a few history books. His country is on the verge.
